Thanks @ChristianMurphy . So if I just want to search with a transformer, my intuition is I should do
GET('path..', ()=>transform()) . However, the type of the second parameter is (data: unknown) => data is T which does not match the transformer passed in. And likewise, if I don't need a queryparam, I would doGET('path..', ()=>validate(), ()=>transform()) , but the third parameter is expected to be object.
I found some people just simply use any as parameters types, or use union types. Is that what we also need to do ?
Typescript's function overloading seems quite different with other languages that I can read. So please correct me if I am very wrong.

nodes.bodyText:
GET('path..', ()=>transform())
GET('path..', ()=>validate(), ()=>transform())

We could support these with lots of overloads.
I'm not sure this is the way we should approach it though.
See #1845 (comment) for alternatives.

any

any tells the compiler to skip type checking, while it is an option, it kinda defeats the purpose of using a typed language 😅
